segments.text: We've been talking about the various buildings and one thing I wanted to ask you in particular to have it on record is I've been told a couple of times who the girl was that was used for a model for the heads on the systems building.
This was Sarah, Sarah Orth.
Sarah Orth was the daughter of Bill Orth.

who came to the college about 1928 or 1929 principally to head the buildings and grounds department at the time, when at the time the college had decided they would erect the library themselves and the first wing on the chemistry building.
She was his daughter, grew up here a number of years on the campus, a very attractive young lady.
Sam Vosper used her as a model for some of the figures decorating the system administration building entrance and main lobby.
So the procedure for making these, whether they were faces or animal heads, was to was to carve one and then make a mold from that and then cast?
You had to make a plaster mold and some
something to set up your molds for making your castings from.
And then thereafter, you cast however many you needed.
And that all was done on campus, too.
That's right.
You mentioned that the college decided to build some of these new buildings on its own.
In other words, it was its own contractor, and it hired the laborers to do all the work.
under whose direction then?
Well, as I said, this W.A.
Orth, a graduate of A&M, I don't remember where he was working when he came here, but he was brought here to head the department and the buildings and college utilities department actually
constructed these buildings, along with another project like extension of utility tunnels and things of that sort.
But I think of those two buildings particularly that were built in that time.
I'm not certain about Hart Hall.
I can't remember when that was contracted.
I'd rather think the college built it, too.
I should know.
I designed the heating system for it at the time.
That was one of the other things I wanted to ask you.
How much of the designing did you personally do on some of the buildings?

Well, principally my work, quite often there was an intermingling of my work with the engineering experiment station, the college architect, because the offices were in the same building, the head man was the same.
Generally, I designed some of the mechanical equipment, in particular
hot water heating systems.
I remember particularly Hart Hall, the dormitory, and Walton Hall, and the Cushing Library, the original heating system and that.
And then of course later when we cut over or changed over the heating of the entire campus, which was a combination of steam heating and hot water heating,
and established a central hot water heating system and converted all buildings that had been steamed to hot water heating.
Well, that was one of my jobs of making the designs for the changeover and the buildings.
That would have been after you came back from the war though?
No, that was in the 30s.
So you did have a
excuse me, central heating system before the war.
Yes, but it didn't include all buildings.

A number of the buildings had a hot water heating system, but they had a heat exchanger in the building which converted steam to hot water or heated the water with steam that was then circulated by gravity through the building.
At that time, we went to forced circulation from a central plant.
Did you make use of any students in any of these building projects?
There were always students used for drafting and other purposes all the time.
Now, of course, primarily in the Big 33 expansion, this was Depression days, and architects and engineers were

quite readily obtainable at that time because there wasn't much construction going on, and we had a full staff of largely adult engineers and architects, although they always had a number of students that did various things, particularly drafting, that is putting the thing on the tracing cloth that had been designed by someone else.
I was particularly asking or interested in whether you used students in
in any of the actual construction, any of the laborers for digging foundations?
Particularly in summer, quite often they were used in that.
It was difficult to use students in many construction jobs because most of the time they didn't have hours that fitted in very well with construction time.
I used quite a number in the buildings and college utilities.
A very large portion of the janitorial service or custodial service in those days was students.
This is pre-World War II.
Yeah.
Were any of the buildings constructed as WPA projects?
I don't believe we had any buildings conducted, but we had other construction projects on the campus, sidewalks, curbs and gutters.
At the time I left, I had a crew out at what was to be Easterwood Airport, a construction crew clearing off the pasture area there so that it could be graded and built.
We made a lot of drainage pipe, concrete pipe, actually set up a plant and made it with WPA labor.
We made a lot of half rounds to use in lining some of the drainage ditches, particularly what is now the golf course.
A number of those creeks were partially lined with half round pipes and small
concrete slabs.
Was that to prevent additional erosion?
Well, it had to clear up so the stuff would drain out and you wouldn't get holes that raised mosquitoes in and things, and that's how you improved the drainage.
Now, I believe a little bit earlier you indicated that in, what, late 1940 you entered the military service.
Yes.
In what capacity did you enter the service?
At that time I was in the infantry.
Olin Teague and I went on duty together on October the 2nd, 1940 at Fort Sam for physical exams.
He wound up with the military police company down at Camp Palacios.
And I was an infantry instructor in the Houston Military District, stationed in Houston initially.
At that time, I was a first lieutenant.
I take it you had remained in military.
I was commissioned a second lieutenant in 1929 on May 26,
And then you remained in what was then the National Guard?
No, I retained my reserve commission.
In fact, the first summer I went on active duty after graduation, I was in the 359th Infantry, which was headquartered in Dallas.
And I had been assigned to them because my home address was Denison, Texas, up north of Dallas.
At the same time, I got to camp another regiment
was there, the 360th, which was composed of Houston and College Station, the southern part of the state area.
And Colonel Ike Ashburn was the colonel commanding the unit.
And Colonel Ashburn at that time was secretary of the Former Students Association, and then later became assistant to the president.
And he was then succeeded by E. McQuillan.
I stayed there in Houston until, I don't know long, about May 1941, just to show you how you might, how assignments might happen.
Back in 34 and 5, I had commanded a camp of two Civilian Conservation Corps companies in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
And I had a lieutenant under my command there named Harold Penny from Arizona.
And I was adjutant in the Houston Military District and infantry instructor there.

One day I was reading the Army and Navy Journal and happened to see a story on the front page about the adjutant general school being set up in Washington, D.C. And on the staff and factory, they listed this Jack Penny.
I had not heard of him since then so I dropped him a note telling him what I was doing and I was adjutant there and this and that.
About a week later I had a call from San Antonio Military District that was in charge of all the reserve activities in the 8th service, 8th corps area it was then.
They told me they had a request for my being transferred to the adjutant general school
And Colonel Jones at the time said, well, Badger, you don't have to go if you don't want to.
We won't release you.
I said, well, that sounds kind of interesting to me.
I think I'll try it.
So I was immediately transferred to the Adjutant General School, the staff and faculty there.
I was assistant editor of the Adjutant General's publications at that time.
Of course, we had gone on active duty
Both Tig and I for six months for training, but we hadn't been on more than a month or so until they extended to a year, and you were supposed to rotate after a year.
So after 13 months, I might as well return to College Station.
I'd been on military leave.
This was before war, before Pearl Harbor, but it was just about time to meet myself going back.

Although when I returned to college, Mr. Gilchrist, who was then dean of engineering, and Mr. Spence, who was then acting vice director of the engineering experiment station, assigned me to Austin to represent the university on the governor's originally industrial staff, which about that time became defense staff, by the time I got there.
And then, so how long did you stay in Austin then?
Well, immediately after Pearl Harbor, I had orders to return to active duty to the infantry school in Fort Benning, Georgia.
And I was working with the Secretary of State quite a bit in Austin.
Bill, I don't know the name of that graduate, by the way.
Anyhow, I told Bill to tell the governor that I was going back to an active duty.
I was a captain at the time.
And next week would be my last over there.
The following week, I came back to close up my office.
And the Secretary of State told me, he said, Howard, I hope you don't mind it, but Governor Stevenson and I called General Donovan.
I told them we just couldn't let you go right now, and he's deferred you for six months.
I told them, well, I wouldn't have done it, but since they've done it, I'll naturally stay.
So I stayed there until June the 1st of 1942, that would be, which time I went on duty to tank the Story Camp Command as Assistant G-1 on General A.D. Bruce's staff at that time.
Where were you stationed at?
At Camp Hood.
Camp Hood, uh-huh.
General Bruce always had a dream then of making Camp Hood a permanent post.
So when it was set up, you had a number of buildings on the
camp painted post headquarters, post this and post that.
Well, of course, the only one that's legal was post engineer.
The rest of them are temporary insulation as a camp and not entitled to be called a post.
And it stayed that way until an inspector general from Washington came through and happened to see them.
And they were immediately repainted with the designation camp instead of post headquarters.
I was the first adjutant.
of Camp Hood and when it was established and moved out from Temple there when we first opened it.
How long did you stay at Camp Hood or Fort Hood as it's known?
Let's see, I got there really finally I think about July the first of 42 and I
I don't remember now whether it was a year or two.
I stayed there until I went to the commanding general staff school at Fort Leavenworth.
And right now I can't remember whether it was the spring of 42 or 43.
After completion of the course there, I was assigned to the 8th Service Command headquarters, which is in Dallas then.
first Director of the Enlisted Section of the Military Personnel Division and later as Director of the Military Personnel Division 8th Service Command.
Did you stay there then until the end of the war or did you have another service somewhere else?
No, I wound up at two other installations.
During the time I was at the Service Command Headquarters,
The technical services installations were transferred from the chief of the service, like the chief surgeon or the chief engineer, to the service commander.
Two of those posts were Camp Claiborne down in Louisiana between Lake Charles and Alexandria.
It was an engineering camp, training center.
and the medical training center out at Barclay.

These commanding officers couldn't remember that they were no longer on the chiefs of services and were under the service command, commanding general instead, and this led to quite a number of problems, and both of them had gotten a pretty bad reputation in the military services anyhow.
So the general set up an investigating board to go to Camp Claiborne and find out what was wrong with it.
And it was my job with some assistance to dig into the personnel set up at Camp Claiborne.
And I admit, while we were there, every time we got anything from the service command headquarters, we were scared to death we were going to be transferred there.
But we got out safely and returned to Dallas.
And a few weeks later, we were sent out to Camp Barkley at Abilene to do the same thing there.
And some months later after return, I was sent out to Camp Barkley to be director of personnel for the camp and begin to close out the installation.
This was in the
long about the time of the Battle of the Bulge.
And then from there I went to camp up at Gainesville, Camp Howes.
As director of personnel, I wasn't there very long.
The commanding officer and I went to service command headquarters a time or so, and each time he came back and said, Badgett, you better thank me.
I can't be out of Claiborne this time.
And one day, he came in after a review.
He was very fond of having reviews on Saturday morning, which I was not great at hearing of.
He came in and called me in the office, stuck out his hand, said, well, goodbye, Batch.
And I said, Carl, who's going, you or me?
He says, you're going to Captain Claiborne.
So I went down there to try to straighten out the personnel situation and that mess.
But I enjoyed both assignments very much.
At what point then did you leave active duty?
I left Claiborne, I believe I went off active duty in February 1946.
Did you return immediately to the A&M then?
Yes.

In fact, knowing I was going to get out soon, I had come over here one weekend to see Mr. Spence, with whom I'd worked with before in the Experiment Station, and he had been assigned a job as head in the Construction Program Office for the college at the time, and of course I was on military leave at the time.
I didn't know whether I'd have a job when I got back or not, but
But to see him he said, Howard says, I've just got so much to do that I'm making enemies out of my friends.
I'm getting so nasty with them.
I need some help and I'd pay you a lot more money to work here and I can't never an experiment station.
So at that time when I returned I went into physical plant work at the university or college at that time.
Did you go in immediately as assistant manager of?
Assistant manager of construction.
Assistant manager of construction.
What, then, were your responsibilities in that position?

Well, at that time, I guess our most pressing job at that time was converting Hart and Walton Halls for family occupancy, making suites of rooms out of them for married veterans who were returning to A&M, as well as completing the construction on what
a conversion of the project houses.
I started to say construction, but they were built during the Depression.
And they were converted to married student housing for graduate students at the time.
Oh, I took over a lot of these jobs, and the planning, and the handling, and various construction projects on the campus.
And then along in that time, we
Buildings and Grounds, or Buildings and Utilities it was called at that time, was under Mr. Spence's nominal direction too.
I took over the administration of the operating end of the buildings and utilities and set up the physical plant department.
landscape or building of the grounds department which had been acting or operating under the head of the floor culture and landscape department and reorganized the thing.
Of course that time Knox Walker was my superintendent of buildings and utilities.
I was unaware of the fact that Hart and Walton had ever been converted to
married student housing.
Well, they left themselves very well to it because it's a suite type of dormitory.
You have two rooms with a connecting bath, laboratory, laboratory in each room.
What we did, we took one room was the sleeping quarters and the other room was the kitchen 9-ed.
We bought some kitchen cabinets and installed them in there.
and stoves.
We piped it with gas.
So each married couple had two rooms in which one you could say was the living room bedroom and the other was the dining room kitchen.
For how long were these two buildings used that way?
Two or three years.
Of course we
You had a decline in students during the war, and then this surge of returning veterans, of which many, many of them were married.
A&M had no married student housing of any sort at that time.
So those were very readily bought beds.
I believe we used the regular dormitory beds.
Bought a dresser, dinette table, chairs, and a few other odds and ends, and put in kitchen stoves, refrigerators, and the kitchen cabinet was seen.
At what point were the barrack type college view buildings either brought in or constructed?
Well, I had charge of that.

These were, I guess in 47 it was started, not terribly long after the war, and we procured these what had been barracks down at Victoria, Texas at Foster Field, and of course the government handled the
contracting of it, actual construction, and our own engineering superintendent on the job.
We had to provide the utilities, walks and streets for it, and the basic plan for it.
And these were dismantled in sections and brought up here in pieces and reassembled and converted from barracks to four or eight apartments each, two on each floor.
Now they've been very serviceable.
The students have generally been very happy with what they had for the money they had.
In fact, there were some protests when this group was torn down for those first new permanent, not Hensel.
Hensel, it was built back of the idea that ultimately the front part, the old barracks apartments would be this amount of torn down and
new apartment houses built there.
And so were the brick ones.
And so were the first brick ones.
And then we did demolish several on this end.
I've forgotten how many, four or five of them.
And built some permanent apartment there.
That's the ones that have just been completed?
No, these were built several years ago.
They were air conditioned.
And then these were built.
I didn't tear down any for those.
I just got rid of the rest of it.
I see they're built on down on what had been the, what Prince Hensel had started as an arboretum.
And they're part of the landscape architecture.
That's the ones right on College Avenue.
Well, I won't say it unless you turn that off.
They may be very nice inside now, and I'm sure they are.
Did your responsibilities as assistant manager for construction of physical plants carry any responsibilities for the annex?
Well, before they required the annex, actually I believe Mr. Spence and I divided responsibilities.
He would handle the new construction, I'd handle the renovation and the maintenance and operation of the physical plant.
And jointly we, I say we acquired, we did the footwork of acquiring the annex.
I remember I had in inventory every piece of what they call personal property out there when we took it over and when we turned it back the first time.
See, we had it twice.
First time they took it over, and then they closed the base down completely.
Well, we had it probably in about 47.
We got it in about 47, I think.
We took it over and we had set up freshmen, moved freshman class out there.
And they lived in one school out there.
The basic, what was called the basic division.
Basic division.
It was what, about four years out there, wasn't it?
Three or four.
I don't remember how long it was.
And then I guess what, during the Korean War, the Air Force took it back over?
That would be when it took it back over and it operated again.
And then we acquired it.
Then after that, on a permanent basis, after they had removed certain buildings and we decided we didn't want,
And we bought it, got it, went on it.
We would get 5% equity in it each year we occupied it.
In other words, in 20 years it would be 100% ours.
Unless we, but some parts we actually bought.
They set a price so we could get them on something they wouldn't have set up, they didn't want to change.
And then later we got rid of most all the other buildings in the room.
Rather, well, the teal theater of operation type construction, the living quarters and a lot of these wooden buildings were kept under the more apartment type, the later hangars and such.
So, but you had some responsibility for converting any of those buildings after?
We set up a branch of the physical plant operation office out there and had a superintendent who worked under the superintendent of the physical plant.
And the ability to tell us I was a director, but then I became director of the physical plant
separated completely from his dispensing room over there.
Okay.
After having been assistant manager, you became the manager of fiscal plans, at least according to the former student's directorate.
Yes, I was the manager of fiscal plans, and then it was later changed to director of fiscal plans.
Was it at that point that you separated from Mr. Spencer's operation?
